newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa reverses at close on mixed selling.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa reverses at close on mixed selling.

text.p: London cocoa futures retreated to negative after a firm start on Thursday following a mixture of selling from origins and disappointed longs.

Traders said sterling appeared to be the main culprit behind the market's weakness as it put the brakes on a recovery since Wednesday after the benchmark March position slipped to a contract low of 951 stg on Wednesday.
"Sterling psychologically gave an excuse to sell," said one trader.
The currency has been buoyed by a UK interest rate hike of a quarter point on Wednesday.
LIFFE cocoa saw good buying at the start of the session which some traders associated with industrial offtake.
But the rally halted at 968 stg a tonne on March and prices reversed back.

Nigeria was an active origin alongside Ivory Coast which is said to be injecting a daily volume of cocoa into forward positions. Traders also cited arbitrage selling after the opening of the New York market.
At the close, March shed eight stg to 956 stg a tonne and spot December was off seven stg at 924 stg. Turnover totalled 9,194 lots but consisted mainly of crosses.
Technical support on March was pegged at 942 stg.
Traders said the market structure was widening with December losing its flavour on concerns that one leading trading house holding large amounts of cocoa could offload its position anytime.
Dec/March traded from 30 to 32 stg on Thursday while May/May was at 65.
Most European markets will be closed on Friday for All Saints Day.
